parts.text:
[Statement 1]: In southeast Australian estuaries, both short and long flexible habitats on subtidal artificial structures showed mixed effects on fish and invertebrate populations.
[Statement 2]: The outcomes of adding flexible habitats to subtidal artificial structures varied by species, survey timing, and habitat characteristics.
[Statement 3]: Long flexible habitats supported macroalgae and non-mobile invertebrate or fish species that were absent from structure surfaces without these habitats.
[Statement 4]: The effect of long flexible habitats on fish species richness around structures depended on which fish were present when the flexible habitats were created.
[Statement 5]: Long flexible habitats had mixed effects on the abundance of fishes or seahorses, with outcomes depending on the species and timing.
[Statement 6]: For invertebrates, long flexible habitats had mixed effects on mobile and non-mobile invertebrate abundance, depending on the species group and survey week.
[Statement 7]: One study reported that flexible habitats decreased mussel abundance on structure surfaces, but the flexible habitats themselves supported a higher biomass than the structure surfaces.
[Statement 8]: Short flexible habitats had mixed effects on mobile and non-mobile invertebrate community composition, with effects depending on the density or length of the flexible habitats.
[Statement 9]: Short flexible habitats had mixed effects on mobile and non-mobile invertebrate abundance, depending on the survey week, species group, and flexible habitat length.
[Statement 10]: Short flexible habitats had mixed effects on seahorse abundance, depending on the survey week.
[Statement 11]: Seahorses used long flexible habitats.
[Statement 12]: Behavioral data was not available for the use of short flexible habitats by seahorses.

key: _claude-sonnet-4__How do the effects of creating short versus long flexible habitats on subtidal artificial structures compare for fish and invertebrate populations in Australia?

parts.text:
[Statement 1]: No studies were found that evaluated the effects of creating large protrusions (>50 mm) on subtidal artificial structures on biodiversity.
[Statement 2]: No evidence exists to indicate whether or not creating large protrusions (>50 mm) on subtidal artificial structures has any desirable or harmful effects.
[Statement 3]: Creating grooves and small protrusions, ridges or ledges (1-50 mm) was examined in three studies from marinas in northern Israel and the UK, and on an open coastline in southeast Spain.
[Statement 4]: Smaller-scale modifications (1-50 mm) on subtidal artificial structures showed mixed effects on biodiversity.
[Statement 5]: Some studies on smaller-scale modifications (1-50 mm) found altered community composition and increased species richness and diversity.
[Statement 6]: Other studies on smaller-scale modifications (1-50 mm) found no increase in species diversity but mixed effects on species richness depending on surface orientation.
[Statement 7]: Creating small protrusions (1-50 mm) alone was examined in one study in Japan.
[Statement 8]: A study in Japan on creating small protrusions (1-50 mm) reported mixed effects on macroalgal abundance depending on the species.
[Statement 9]: Textured surfaces (≤1 mm) were examined in three studies from Italy, Israel, and the USA.
[Statement 10]: Studies on textured surfaces (≤1 mm) showed variable effects on community composition, richness, and abundance.

key: _claude-sonnet-4__What is the evidence base for the effectiveness of creating large protrusions or ridges (>50 mm) on subtidal artificial structures?

parts.text:
[Statement 1]: Ten studies examined the effects of transplanting or seeding species onto intertidal artificial structures.
[Statement 2]: Seven of these studies were conducted in estuaries in southeast Australia and Hong Kong.
[Statement 3]: Three studies in Hong Kong and Australia reported that oysters transplanted onto intertidal artificial structures supported macroalgae, mobile invertebrate, non-mobile invertebrate and fish species.
[Statement 4]: The supported species were absent from structure surfaces that did not have transplanted oysters.
[Statement 5]: Three studies found that transplanting oysters had mixed effects on combined macroalgae and invertebrate species richness and/or diversity on structure surfaces.
[Statement 6]: The mixed effects on species richness and/or diversity depended on the site and/or the presence and size of grooves and small ridges or ledges on the surfaces.
[Statement 7]: One study in Australia found that transplanting oysters increased mobile invertebrate species richness on structure surfaces.
[Statement 8]: Two of three studies in Australia found that transplanting oysters and/or coralline algae did not increase fish species richness on and around structure surfaces.
[Statement 9]: One study found mixed effects of transplanting oysters and/or coralline algae on fish species richness, with the effects depending on surface features and site.
[Statement 10]: Two studies in Australia found mixed effects on combined macroalgae and invertebrate abundance, depending on surface features.
[Statement 11]: Two of three studies in Hong Kong and Australia found that transplanting oysters had mixed effects on mobile invertebrate abundance depending on surface features and/or site.
[Statement 12]: One study found that transplanting oysters increased non-mobile invertebrate and oyster recruit abundance.
[Statement 13]: The same study that found an increase in some invertebrates also found a decreased abundance of barnacles.
[Statement 14]: Two of three studies in Australia found that transplanting oysters and/or coralline algae did not increase fish abundance on and around structure surfaces.
[Statement 15]: Six of eight studies in Australia, Spain, Singapore and Hong Kong reported that the survival of transplanted mobile and non-mobile invertebrates varied depending on species, site, and/or the presence and size of surface features.
[Statement 16]: Higher oyster survival was reported when oysters were transplanted into grooves compared with on ridges.
[Statement 17]: One study in Australia found that transplanting oysters and/or coralline algae did not increase the time fishes spent interacting with structure surfaces or the number of bites taken.
[Statement 18]: The same study found that benthic fishes took more bites from surfaces with transplanted oysters than from surfaces with transplanted algae and oysters together.

key: _claude-sonnet-4__What are the observed outcomes of transplanting or seeding organisms onto intertidal artificial structures in Australian estuaries?

parts.text:
[Statement 1]: Several habitat creation methods are effective for increasing species richness and diversity on intertidal artificial structures.
[Statement 2]: Rock pools are among the most consistently effective methods for increasing combined macroalgae, invertebrate and/or fish species diversity and/or richness.
[Statement 3]: Rock pools supported species that were absent from structure surfaces without pools.
[Statement 4]: Pit habitats of 1-50 mm showed strong effectiveness for increasing combined macroalgae and invertebrate species richness and/or diversity.
[Statement 5]: Pit habitats supported macroalgae, invertebrate and/or fish species that were absent from surfaces without added habitats.
[Statement 6]: Hole habitats larger than 50 mm demonstrated consistent positive effects in increasing combined macroalgae and invertebrate species diversity and/or richness.
[Statement 7]: Hole habitats supported species that were absent from structure surfaces without added habitat features.
[Statement 8]: Combinations of grooves and small ridges or ledges of 1-50 mm showed effectiveness in increasing combined macroalgae and invertebrate species diversity and/or richness.
[Statement 9]: Combinations of grooves and small ridges or ledges supported species that were absent from structure surfaces without these features.
[Statement 10]: Groove habitats of 1-50 mm, when used alone, showed mixed results for increasing species richness and/or diversity.
[Statement 11]: Grooves consistently supported species that were absent from structure surfaces without grooves.
[Statement 12]: Small protrusions of 1-50 mm, when combined with other habitat types, showed positive effects on increasing combined macroalgae and invertebrate species richness.
[Statement 13]: Small ridges or ledges of 1-50 mm, when used alone, showed limited effectiveness, with mixed results.
[Statement 14]: Small ridges or ledges typically supported lower species richness than the grooves created between them.
[Statement 15]: Large ridges or ledges greater than 50 mm showed inconsistent results for increasing species diversity.
[Statement 16]: Textured surfaces of 1 mm or less had mixed effects on species richness, depending on the type of texture and the site.
[Statement 17]: Short flexible habitats of 1-50 mm decreased combined species richness in one study.
[Statement 18]: Creating water-retaining features like rock pools, holes, and pits is most effective for enhancing species richness and diversity on intertidal artificial structures.
[Statement 19]: Creating three-dimensional complexity through combinations of habitat types is most effective for enhancing species richness and diversity on intertidal artificial structures.

key: _claude-sonnet-4__Which habitat creation methods are most effective for increasing overall species richness and diversity on intertidal artificial structures?

parts.text:
[Statement 1]: In European marine environments, the outcomes of creating textured surfaces on intertidal structures vary considerably depending on the type of texture created, the specific site, and the species being measured.
[Statement 2]: Studies from the UK and Netherlands demonstrate that creating textured surfaces (≤1 mm) had mixed effects on combined macroalgae and invertebrate species richness on structure surfaces.
[Statement 3]: The outcomes of creating textured surfaces on combined macroalgae and invertebrate species richness depended on both the type of texture created and the site.
[Statement 4]: Creating textured surfaces, along with using environmentally-sensitive material, had mixed effects on barnacle and mobile invertebrate abundances, depending on the site.
[Statement 5]: One study found that creating textured surfaces increased barnacle abundance regardless of texture type.
[Statement 6]: Different surface textures supported different abundances of barnacles.
[Statement 7]: According to two studies in the Netherlands, creating textured surfaces did not increase macroalgal abundance on structure surfaces.
[Statement 8]: Creating natural rocky reef topography on intertidal structures in the UK had mixed effects on barnacle and mobile invertebrate abundances depending on the site.
[Statement 9]: Creating natural rocky reef topography on intertidal structures in the UK did not increase combined macroalgae and invertebrate species richness.
[Statement 10]: Natural topography on intertidal structures was colonized by macroalgae and limpets.
[Statement 11]: Limpets used shaded grooves and water-retaining depressions on surfaces with natural topography.
[Statement 12]: Creating groove habitats (1-50 mm) on intertidal structures showed varied outcomes across European studies.
[Statement 13]: In the UK and Netherlands, creating groove habitats did not increase macroalgal abundance on structure surfaces according to two studies.
[Statement 14]: Three of four studies from Australia, the Netherlands and the UK found that creating groove habitats did not increase invertebrate, limpet or chiton abundances.
[Statement 15]: Groove habitats were reported to be used by mussels and periwinkles in Netherlands studies.
[Statement 16]: Creating pit habitats (1-50 mm) on intertidal structures showed variable outcomes in European environments.
[Statement 17]: Studies from the UK and Netherlands found that creating pit habitats did not increase macroalgal abundance on structure surfaces according to three of four studies.
[Statement 18]: For invertebrates, studies in the Netherlands and UK found mixed results when creating pit habitats.
[Statement 19]: Some studies in the Netherlands and UK showed no increase in invertebrate abundance in pit habitats.
[Statement 20]: Other studies in the Netherlands and UK found mixed effects on barnacle and mobile invertebrate abundances in pit habitats, depending on site, species, animal size, and pit characteristics.
[Statement 21]: Combined modifications on intertidal structures involving grooves and small protrusions, ridges or ledges (1-50 mm) demonstrated varied outcomes depending on multiple factors.
[Statement 22]: UK studies found that combined surface modifications had mixed effects on mobile invertebrate, non-mobile invertebrate, limpet, mussel, juvenile oyster and barnacle abundances.
[Statement 23]: The outcomes of combined surface modifications depended on the depth or height of grooves and ridges, the presence of large ledges or water-retaining and light-shading covers, the shore level, and the site.

key: _claude-sonnet-4__In European marine environments, how do the outcomes of creating textured surfaces on intertidal structures vary?

parts.text:
[Statement 1]: Several actions can enhance fish communities on subtidal artificial structures based on available evidence.
[Statement 2]: Creating structural habitat features shows promise for enhancing fish communities on subtidal artificial structures.
[Statement 3]: Long flexible habitats over 50 mm supported fish species that were absent from structure surfaces without such flexible habitats.
[Statement 4]: Long flexible habitats had mixed effects on fish abundance depending on the species and the presence of fish when the habitats were created.
[Statement 5]: Small adjoining cavities or 'swimthrough' habitats of 100 mm or less supported six fish species that were absent from structure surfaces without swimthroughs.
[Statement 6]: Small adjoining cavities or 'swimthrough' habitats had mixed effects on juvenile fish community composition and abundance, depending on the site and survey conditions.
[Statement 7]: Large adjoining cavities or 'swimthrough' habitats greater than 100 mm supported fish species that were absent from structure surfaces without swimthroughs.
[Statement 8]: Large adjoining cavities or 'swimthrough' habitats increased overall fish species richness and abundance.
[Statement 9]: When large adjoining cavities or 'swimthrough' habitats were added, individual species responses varied.
[Statement 10]: Creating hole habitats over 50 mm, combined with features like grooves and pits, supported fish species that were absent from structure surfaces without these added features.
[Statement 11]: The effects on fish abundance from adding hole habitats with grooves and pits were mixed, depending on the species group.
[Statement 12]: Groove habitats between 1 and 50 mm, when combined with holes, pits, and environmentally-sensitive material, supported fish species that were absent from similar structures without these added features.
[Statement 13]: The addition of groove habitats combined with other features had mixed effects on fish abundances depending on the species group.
[Statement 14]: Management approaches, such as harvesting restrictions, also show benefits for fish communities on artificial structures.
[Statement 15]: Harvesting restrictions supported fish species that were absent from unrestricted structures and led to higher fish species richness.
[Statement 16]: The effects of harvesting restrictions on total fish abundance were mixed.
[Statement 17]: Reducing maintenance activities on artificial structures can increase seahorse abundance on the structure surfaces.
[Statement 18]: Using environmentally-sensitive materials like ECOncrete™ combined with habitat features supported fish species that were absent from standard-concrete or fibreglass structure surfaces.
[Statement 19]: The effects of using environmentally-sensitive materials on fish abundances were mixed, depending on the species group.
[Statement 20]: Creating artificial reefs with different 3-D structures and materials showed no consistent differences in combined mobile invertebrate and fish richness or abundance between different reef designs.

key: _claude-sonnet-4__What actions can enhance fish communities on subtidal artificial structures?

parts.text:
[Statement 1]: Outcomes from using environmentally-sensitive materials on subtidal artificial structures in Israel, the UK, and Australia vary significantly by location and material type.
[Statement 2]: In Israel, using ECOncrete™ in place of standard concrete, along with creating texture, grooves, holes, pits and small ledges, altered the combined macroalgae and invertebrate community composition.

[Statement 8]: In Australia, studies found that using quarried rock or shell-concrete in place of standard-concrete had mixed effects on community composition and species richness depending on the site and surface orientation.

parts.text:

parts.text:
[Statement 1]: Based on multiple studies across various geographic locations, several habitat modifications have been consistently effective for altering ecological communities on intertidal artificial structures.

[Statement 4]: Creating pit habitats increased species richness in eight of 12 studies.
[Statement 5]: Pit habitats supported macroalgae, invertebrate and fish species that were absent from unmodified surfaces.
[Statement 6]: Groove habitats of 1-50 mm demonstrated consistent effectiveness across 14 studies.

[Statement 8]: Creating grooves increased combined macroalgae and invertebrate species richness in three of six studies.
[Statement 9]: Grooves and pits supported species absent from surfaces without these modifications.
[Statement 10]: Flexible habitats showed promise with both long (greater than 50 mm) and short (1-50 mm) versions altering community composition.

[Statement 12]: Short flexible habitats altered the combined community composition of macroalgae and non-mobile invertebrates.
[Statement 13]: Hole habitats larger than 50 mm consistently increased species diversity and richness across three studies.

[Statement 15]: Hole habitats larger than 50 mm supported species absent from unmodified surfaces.

parts.text:
[Statement 1]: The evidence for creating adjoining cavities or 'swimthrough' habitats on artificial structures varies significantly between subtidal and intertidal zones.
[Statement 2]: The effectiveness of creating adjoining cavities or 'swimthrough' habitats on artificial structures depends on cavity size.

[Statement 6]: One study found that large swimthroughs (>100 mm) on subtidal structures increased overall fish species richness and abundance on the surfaces of the structures.
[Statement 7]: The effects of large swimthroughs on subtidal structures varied by fish size class and species.

[Statement 9]: For intertidal structures, the evidence for creating swimthrough habitats is much more limited.
[Statement 10]: Small swimthrough habitats (≤100 mm) on intertidal structures did not alter mobile invertebrate community composition.
[Statement 11]: Small swimthrough habitats on intertidal structures did not increase species richness or diversity.
[Statement 12]: Small swimthrough habitats on intertidal structures did increase mobile invertebrate abundance on the surfaces of the structures.
[Statement 13]: No studies were found that evaluated large swimthrough habitats (>100 mm) on intertidal artificial structures.

parts.text:

parts.text:
[Statement 1]: Creating grooves and small protrusions, ridges, or ledges on artificial structures in marine environments simultaneously produces several ecological effects.
[Statement 2]: On intertidal structures, creating grooves and small protrusions, ridges, or ledges alters the combined macroalgae and invertebrate community composition.

parts.text:
[Statement 1]: Creating rock pools on intertidal artificial structures shows variable biodiversity outcomes across different geographical locations.
[Statement 2]: Studies on the biodiversity outcomes of creating rock pools on intertidal artificial structures were conducted across multiple regions.
[Statement 3]: Ten studies on rock pools were conducted in estuaries in Australia, the UK and eastern USA.
[Statement 4]: Five studies on rock pools were conducted on open coastlines in the UK, Ireland and southeast Spain.
[Statement 5]: Two studies on rock pools were conducted in straits in the UK and Malaysia.
[Statement 6]: One study on rock pools was conducted in a marina in Australia.
[Statement 7]: In Ireland, shore level and wave-exposure affected the community composition of created rock pools.
[Statement 8]: In Ireland, wave-sheltered rock pools filled with sediment within two years.
[Statement 9]: In Australia, the effectiveness of created rock pools varied by pool depth, shore level and site.
[Statement 10]: In Australia, created rock pools had mixed effects on community composition depending on pool depth, shore level and site.
[Statement 11]: Studies in Australia, the UK, Spain and Malaysia found that rock pools generally supported macroalgae, mobile invertebrate, non-mobile invertebrate and/or fish species that were absent from structure surfaces without pools.
[Statement 12]: Nine of twelve replicated, controlled studies in Australia, the UK, Spain and Malaysia found rock pools supported higher combined macroalgae, invertebrate and/or fish species diversity and/or richness than structure surfaces without pools.
[Statement 13]: Three studies reported similar species richness between created rock pools and structure surfaces without pools.
[Statement 14]: The geographical location of rock pools also influenced functional outcomes.
[Statement 15]: One study found that functional richness was lower in high-shore pools than mid-shore pools.
[Statement 16]: Rock pool characteristics interacted differently with environmental conditions across locations.
[Statement 17]: Two studies found that pool depth did not affect community composition.
[Statement 18]: Wave exposure and shore level had varying effects on rock pool communities depending on the specific site location.
[Statement 19]: The effectiveness of rock pools in supporting biodiversity appears to be influenced by local environmental conditions including wave exposure, shore level, and site-specific factors that vary by geographical region.
